thread.title: Watch the journey your bag takes once you check it at the airport
thread.title_full: Watch the journey your bag takes once you check it at the airport - MarketWatch

author: Silvia Ascarelli
title: Watch the journey your bag takes once you check it at the airport
text:
This is what happens to the 47 million pieces of luggage that are handled each year at Schipohl Airport in Amsterdam:
Some 55 million people travel through Schipohl annually, making it Europe’s fifth-busiest airport. The airport relies on an automated transportation system called the Backbone as well as robots to help move the luggage to and from planes.
It takes at least 25 minutes for a bag to travel from check-in to airplane, according to the airport , in which Aeroports de Paris SA ADP, -0.28% owns a minority stake. But it can take at least 40 minutes to 50 minutes for bags being transferred from one flight to another — which is what happens to 40% of all suitcases.
Schipohl’s technology includes eight robots in its South Hall, under the air-traffic control tower, and a “mechanical unloading module” in Hall D that can lift a container of baggage, tip it over and empty it onto a loading quay, or lateral.
While technology is used to move baggage, washing the outside of a plane is done by hand, as this second video shows. It can take five people seven hours to scrub down a Boeing BA, +0.11% 737, but it takes at least 10 people to do the job in one shift for a widebody jet.
